Situation1: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: An external inspector has raised immediate concerns that could halt operations unless issues are resolved
Story: I stared at my calendar, heart pounding. The team meeting was about to start—our last chance to weigh in before the project’s direction was set in stone. As a colleague, I was expected to be there, to contribute, to show I was invested in our shared goals. But just as I was about to log in, my phone buzzed. The external inspector’s voice was urgent: safety compliance issues had surfaced, and if I didn’t address them now, operations could be shut down. As the engineer, it was my responsibility to drop everything and ensure we met every standard, no matter what. My teammates were counting on me to help shape our future, but the company was counting on me to keep us running safely. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down, each demanding my full attention at the exact same moment. My mind raced, caught between loyalty to my team and duty to my profession, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left behind.
